story.name: b0af505c-76c2-4888-a5ad-3f0a5f3a84bb
story.title: Aston Martin Raises $150 Million to Help Fund SUV Launch
story.summary: PYDLSOSYF01T(Bloomberg) -- Aston Martin Lagonda Global Holdings Plc raised $150 million in a bond sale to help ease liquidity concerns as the carmaker awaits a cash-flow boost from deliveries of its DBX luxury SUV.A further $100 million of notes could be sold next year, Gaydon, England-based Aston Martin said Wednesday. Bloomberg reported this month that the company might return to the bond market after a $190 million placement in April.Aston Martin is staking future growth on a predicted...

xmlText.p: (Bloomberg) -- Aston Martin Lagonda Global Holdings Plc raised $150 million in a bond sale to help ease liquidity concerns as the carmaker awaits a cash-flow boost from deliveries of its DBX luxury SUV.

A further $100 million of notes could be sold next year, Gaydon, England-based Aston Martin said Wednesday. Bloomberg reported this month that the company might return to the bond market after a $190 million placement in April.

Aston Martin is staking future growth on a predicted sales surge from the DBX, which will be built at a new factory in Wales that opened in June. In the meantime, the carmaker has been treading water while confronting a weaker auto market and challenges from Brexit and global trade wars.

Chief Executive Officer Andy Palmer said the bond issue amounts to “insurance to make the bridge to DBX.” He said the company remains confident about demand for the model, with conditions for the potential second tranche of bonds specifying orders of 1,400 cars by the middle of next year.
Shares of Aston Martin traded 0.3% higher at 576.60 pence as of 8:03 a.m. in London. The stock has slumped 53% this year, valuing the company at 1.3 billion pounds ($1.6 billion).
Palmer said the DBX will be unveiled without camouflage in December and will be on the road toward the end of the second quarter next year.

“If you speak to most people, the concerns are can they get to DBX and do they have enough cash?” he said in an interview. “Both these tranches are closed and we will have the money in the bank. That should allay fears.”
The U.K. carmaker generated about 900,000 pounds of cash from operations in the first half, the lowest since it started to disclose earnings, data compiled by Bloomberg show.
(Updates with comments from CEO from fourth paragraph.)
To contact the reporter on this story: Siddharth Philip in London at sphilip3@bloomberg.net
To contact the editors responsible for this story: Tara Patel at tpatel2@bloomberg.net, Christopher Jasper, Andrew Noël
